trans-unit.source: Configuring Python with Azure App Service Web Apps
trans-unit.target: Configuring Python with Azure App Service Web Apps

trans-unit.source: This tutorial describes options for authoring and configuring a basic Web server Gateway Interface (WSGI) compliant Python application on Azure App Service Web Apps.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial describes options for authoring and configuring a basic Web server Gateway Interface (WSGI) compliant Python application on Azure App Service Web Apps.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial describes options for authoring and configuring a basic Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) compliant Python application on <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial describes options for authoring and configuring a basic Web Server Gateway Interface (WSGI) compliant Python application on <linkText>Azure App Service Web Apps</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: It describes additional features of Git deployment, such as virtual environment and package installation using requirements.txt.
trans-unit.target: It describes additional features of Git deployment, such as virtual environment and package installation using requirements.txt.

trans-unit.source: The Azure Marketplace contains templates for the Bottle, Django and Flask frameworks.
trans-unit.target: The Azure Marketplace contains templates for the Bottle, Django and Flask frameworks.

trans-unit.source: If you are developing your first web app in Azure App Service, or you are not familiar with Git, we recommend that you follow one of these tutorials, which include step-by-step instructions for building a working application from the gallery using Git deployment from Windows or Mac:
trans-unit.target: If you are developing your first web app in Azure App Service, or you are not familiar with Git, we recommend that you follow one of these tutorials, which include step-by-step instructions for building a working application from the gallery using Git deployment from Windows or Mac:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating web apps with Bottle</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating web apps with Bottle</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating web apps with Django</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating web apps with Django</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Creating web apps with Flask</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Creating web apps with Flask</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.source: This tutorial assumes an existing Azure subscription and access to the Azure Preview Portal.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial assumes an existing Azure subscription and access to the Azure Preview Portal.

trans-unit.source: If you do not have an existing web app, you can create one from the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you do not have an existing web app, you can create one from the <linkText>Azure Preview Portal</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Click the NEW button in the bottom left corner, then click Web + Mobile > Web app.
trans-unit.target: Click the NEW button in the bottom left corner, then click Web + Mobile > Web app.

trans-unit.source: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: Configure Git publishing for your newly created web app by following the instructions at <linkText>Continuous deployment using GIT in Azure App Service</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: This tutorial uses Git to create, manage, and publish our Python web app to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: This tutorial uses Git to create, manage, and publish our Python web app to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: Once Git publishing is set up, a Git repository will be created and associated with your web app.
trans-unit.target: Once Git publishing is set up, a Git repository will be created and associated with your web app.

trans-unit.source: The repository's URL will be displayed and can henceforth be used to push data from the local development environment to the cloud.
trans-unit.target: The repository's URL will be displayed and can henceforth be used to push data from the local development environment to the cloud.

trans-unit.source: To publish applications via Git, make sure a Git client is also installed and use the instructions provided to push your web app content to Azure App Service.
trans-unit.target: To publish applications via Git, make sure a Git client is also installed and use the instructions provided to push your web app content to Azure App Service.

trans-unit.source: In the next sections, the following files are created.
trans-unit.target: In the next sections, the following files are created.

trans-unit.source: They should be placed in the root of the Git repository.
trans-unit.target: They should be placed in the root of the Git repository.

trans-unit.source: WSGI is a Python standard described by <linkText>PEP 3333</linkText><title></title> defining an interface between the web server and Python.
trans-unit.target: WSGI is a Python standard described by <linkText>PEP 3333</linkText><title></title> defining an interface between the web server and Python.

trans-unit.source: It provides a standardized interface for writing various web applications and frameworks using Python.
trans-unit.target: It provides a standardized interface for writing various web applications and frameworks using Python.

trans-unit.source: Popular Python web frameworks today use WSGI.
trans-unit.target: Popular Python web frameworks today use WSGI.

trans-unit.source: Azure App Service Web Apps gives you support for any such frameworks; in addition, advanced users can even author their own as long as the custom handler follows the WSGI specification guidelines.
trans-unit.target: Azure App Service Web Apps gives you support for any such frameworks; in addition, advanced users can even author their own as long as the custom handler follows the WSGI specification guidelines.

trans-unit.source: Here's an example of an app.py that defines a custom handler:
trans-unit.target: Here's an example of an app.py that defines a custom handler:

trans-unit.source: You can run this application locally with python app.py, then browse to http://localhost:5555 in your web browser.
trans-unit.target: You can run this application locally with python app.py, then browse to http://localhost:5555 in your web browser.

trans-unit.source: Although the example app above doesn't require any external packages, it is likely that your application will require some.
trans-unit.target: Although the example app above doesn't require any external packages, it is likely that your application will require some.

trans-unit.source: To help manage external package dependencies, Azure Git deployment supports the creation of virtual environments.
trans-unit.target: To help manage external package dependencies, Azure Git deployment supports the creation of virtual environments.

trans-unit.source: When Azure detects a requirements.txt in the root of the repository, it automatically creates a virtual environment named env.
trans-unit.target: When Azure detects a requirements.txt in the root of the repository, it automatically creates a virtual environment named env.

trans-unit.source: This only occurs on the first deployment, or during any deployment after the selected Python runtime has changed.
trans-unit.target: This only occurs on the first deployment, or during any deployment after the selected Python runtime has changed.

trans-unit.source: You will probably want to create a virtual environment locally for development, but don't include it in your Git repository.
trans-unit.target: You will probably want to create a virtual environment locally for development, but don't include it in your Git repository.

trans-unit.source: Packages listed in requirements.txt will be installed automatically in the virtual environment using pip.
trans-unit.target: Packages listed in requirements.txt will be installed automatically in the virtual environment using pip.

trans-unit.source: This happens on every deployment, but pip will skip installation if a package is already installed.
trans-unit.target: This happens on every deployment, but pip will skip installation if a package is already installed.

trans-unit.source: Example requirements.txt:
trans-unit.target: Example requirements.txt:

trans-unit.source: Example runtime.txt:
trans-unit.target: Example runtime.txt:

trans-unit.source: You'll need to create a web.config file to specify how the server should handle requests.
trans-unit.target: You'll need to create a web.config file to specify how the server should handle requests.

trans-unit.source: Note that if you have a web.x.y.config file in your repository, where x.y matches the selected Python runtime, then Azure will automatically copy the appropriate file as web.config.
trans-unit.target: Note that if you have a web.x.y.config file in your repository, where x.y matches the selected Python runtime, then Azure will automatically copy the appropriate file as web.config.

trans-unit.source: The following web.config examples rely on a virtual environment proxy script, which is described in the next section.
trans-unit.target: The following web.config examples rely on a virtual environment proxy script, which is described in the next section.

trans-unit.source: They work with the WSGI handler used in the example app.py above.
trans-unit.target: They work with the WSGI handler used in the example app.py above.

trans-unit.source: Example web.config for Python 2.7:
trans-unit.target: Example web.config for Python 2.7:

trans-unit.source: Example web.config for Python 3.4:
trans-unit.target: Example web.config for Python 3.4:

trans-unit.source: Static files will be handled by the web server directly, without going through Python code, for improved performance.
trans-unit.target: Static files will be handled by the web server directly, without going through Python code, for improved performance.

trans-unit.source: In the above examples, the location of the static files on disk should match the location in the URL.
trans-unit.target: In the above examples, the location of the static files on disk should match the location in the URL.

trans-unit.source: This means that a request for http://pythonapp.azurewebsites.net/static/site.css will serve the file on disk at \static\site.css.
trans-unit.target: This means that a request for http://pythonapp.azurewebsites.net/static/site.css will serve the file on disk at \static\site.css.

trans-unit.source: It's possible configure the rule Static Files to serve files from a location on disk that differs from the location in the URL.
trans-unit.target: It's possible configure the rule Static Files to serve files from a location on disk that differs from the location in the URL.

trans-unit.source: In the following rule definition, a request for http://pythonapp.azurewebsites.net/static/site.css will serve the file on disk at \FlaskWebProject\static\site.css, instead of \static\site.css.
trans-unit.target: In the following rule definition, a request for http://pythonapp.azurewebsites.net/static/site.css will serve the file on disk at \FlaskWebProject\static\site.css, instead of \static\site.css.

trans-unit.source: WSGI_ALT_VIRTUALENV_HANDLER is where you specify the WSGI handler.
trans-unit.target: WSGI_ALT_VIRTUALENV_HANDLER is where you specify the WSGI handler.

trans-unit.source: In the above examples, it's app.wsgi_app because the handler is a function named wsgi_app in app.py in the root folder.
trans-unit.target: In the above examples, it's app.wsgi_app because the handler is a function named wsgi_app in app.py in the root folder.

trans-unit.source: PYTHONPATH can be customized, but if you install all your dependencies in the virtual environment by specifying them in requirements.txt, you shouldn't need to change it.
trans-unit.target: PYTHONPATH can be customized, but if you install all your dependencies in the virtual environment by specifying them in requirements.txt, you shouldn't need to change it.

trans-unit.source: The following script is used to retrieve the WSGI handler, activate the virtual environment and log errors.
trans-unit.target: The following script is used to retrieve the WSGI handler, activate the virtual environment and log errors.

trans-unit.source: It is designed to be generic and used without modifications.
trans-unit.target: It is designed to be generic and used without modifications.

trans-unit.source: Contents of ptvs_virtualenv_proxy.py:
trans-unit.target: Contents of ptvs_virtualenv_proxy.py:

trans-unit.source: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.
trans-unit.target: If you want to get started with Azure App Service before signing up for an Azure account, go to <linkText>Try App Service</linkText><title></title>, where you can immediately create a short-lived starter web app in App Service.

trans-unit.source: No credit cards required; no commitments.
trans-unit.target: No credit cards required; no commitments.

trans-unit.source: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>
trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change from Websites to App Service see: <linkText>Azure App Service and Its Impact on Existing Azure Services</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: For a guide to the change of the old portal to the new portal see: <linkText>Reference for navigating the preview portal</linkText><title></title>
